_header: Sir John Mandeville and Sir Mark of Venice
Title(s): ‘Off the Grete Caan Emperour of Tartaria’
_description: John Mandeville, ‘Off the Grete Caan Emperour of Tartaria’, an extract from Mandeville’s Travels — 313 lines in 8-line stanzas

BodeMus160.First Lines:
[ ]ll & sir Marc of Veneese[ ]both of suth do
                    saye…
BodeMus160.Last Lines:
…In all lust & plesur doth ey lyeThus ar they blyndid
                    wortherly
BodeMus160.Attributed Title: Off the grete Caan Emperour of tartaria (f. 113v)

Wright,  Thomas,  and  James Orchard Halliwell-Phillipps, eds.

             Remains of the Early Popular Poetry of England.
         London: J. R. Smith, 1864-6: 1.155-58 (lines 185-282).
Seymour,  M. C. 
             “Mandeville and Marco Polo: A Stanzaic Fragment.” 
             Journal of the Australasian Universities Language and Literature
